thread.title: WATER POLO: Area teams struggle at top tournaments
thread.title_full: WATER POLO: Area teams struggle at top tournaments - Press Enterprise

author: KYLE GLASER
title: WATER POLO: Area teams struggle at top tournaments
text:
BY KYLE GLASER / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 5, 2015 Updated: 10:00 p.m. WATER POLO: Area teams struggle at top tournaments Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 2 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » SPOTLIGHT GAMES
Thursday, King at Santiago: The bitter rivals face off for Big VIII League surpremacy and likely a share of the league title
Thursday, Murrieta Valley at Vista Murrieta: Battle of two of the top four teams in Div. 3 is also a fierce league and city rivalry
Oct. 15, North at Poly: Huskies are quietly surging but need to knock off powerful Bears to prove they're for real
SPOTLIGHT PLAYERS
Anthony Diaz, Sr., Jurupa Valley: Goalkeeper came up with 13 saves lead Jaguars to win in San Gorgonio tournament championship game
Michael Swieca, Jr., Poly: Team captain has been rolling lately with 18 goals and four asissts in last four games
Jack Wanta, Jr., Hemet: Driver led Bulldogs through Diamond Bar tournament with 14 goals, eight steals and 14 ejections drawn in five contests
The best boys water polo programs the Inland area has to offer didn’t fare so hot against other regions’ top programs.
Local programs participated in three top-flight 32-team tournaments in recent weeks, and none managed to finish in the top eight at any of them.
At the Amercia’s Finest City Tournament in Corona – largely considered the top tournament in the state – Murrieta Valley finished 10th and was the best of the Inland programs.
Riverside King finished 19th, Lake Elsinore Temescal Canyon 22nd, and Elsinore in the bottom quarter of the field. At the next week’s Villa Park Tournament, King, Temescal Canyon and Corona Santiago all finished out of the top eight.
Riverside Poly went to the South Coast Varsity Tournament and could only manage a 21st-place finish.
League play begins across the area this week, meaning there isn’t much local programs can do to improve the Inland area’s tournament résumé for 2015. The only top-tier tournament remaining is the Steve Pal Tournament, hosted by Villa Park
NIGHTHAWKS NO. 1
Murrieta Valley jumped to the top spot in this week’s CIF-Southern Section Division 3 poll, the first time all season the Nighthawks are ranked No. 1
Murrieta Valley was ranked No. 3 last week but jumped Laguna Beach and Capistrano Valley for the top spot. The Nighthawks beat Laguna Beach, the previous No. 2, on Saturday, 12-7.
Fellow Southwestern League squad Vista Murrieta is ranked No. 4 in the Division 3 poll for the second straight week.
The Division 5 poll has a strong Citrus Belt League presence with features Redlands (No. 3), Redlands East Valley (No. 6) and Yucaipa (No. 7) all ranked, Lake Elsinore Temescal Canyon comes in at No. 2 in the Division 6 poll and Jurupa Valley is No. 5 in Division 7.
SUPER SOPH
Riverside Arlington’s David Carazo is on a blistering scoring pace.
The sophomore driver has 86 goals and 20 assists in 14 games, giving him an area-high 106 points according to MaxPreps.
Carazo has been particularly dominant with 29 goals in his last four games, during which the Lions are 4-0.
He also has 61 steals and 36 ejections drawn.
JC STANDOUTS
A number of former local high school standouts are making an impact at the junior college level.
For Riverside City College, Kyle Christian (King) has five goals and five assists and Jonah Saenz (Poly) has six goals through two games of conference play. Goalkeeper Dustin Shaw (King) has 15 saves.
Adam Kelsey (Temecula Great Oak) is the starting goalkeeper at Palomar and has made 77 saves with only three goals allowed in eight games and Noah Borin (Murrieta Valley) is averaging four saves per game while splitting time in net at Long Beach City College.
Contact the writer: kglaser@pe.com
